messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:47): there is some irony to the way that microsoft suggests xxx has a security problem when in fact xdr is the one increasing the attack surface
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:54): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: there's a line missing from InFrameset to AfterFrameset
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:54): unless the spec itself is wrong somehow
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:54): let me know if i'm being inconsistent or something
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (20:55): notes that #writing is not in sync with #parsing
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:55): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Oops, that's because my spec-to-code regexp thing is incomplete and fails to understand that bit of text
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:56): It's missing after-after-(body|frameset) -> in-\1 for the same reason
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (20:56): is sad that <http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/2008/03/18/happy-easter> kinda-sorta-half-updated postMessage
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:56): ah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:56): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: oh?
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (20:57): but it uses uri/domain
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:57): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: It would be much easier for me if you wrote the spec in OCaml instead of English
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (20:57): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: that's your objective opinion?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:58): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: i believe you
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (20:58): namely entities in escaping text spans (in rcdata)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:59): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: i'm happy to make my text more self-consistent (i did a lot of changes to that effect recently so you should be able to simplify your regexps) but it's staying in english :-)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:01): i also found that #writing didn't say anything about the LF and <listing>, but then i remembered that <listing> is not valid in the first place :)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:02): but #serialising should talk about that
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:04): speaking of serializing, i think the algorithm should change for (r)cdata elements to only emit the children text and cdata nodes
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:05): (including plaintext)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:06): less checking (hence better perf) and better roundtripping (comments are not turned into text but are instead just dropped)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:06): and it's what firefox does, i think
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:08): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: please send e-mail, i'm working on tables at the moment
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:27): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: is the windows safari 3.1 still labelled a beta?)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:32): cool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:33): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: the perf aspect is purely an implementation detail
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:34): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: how should the XML "<textarea><div> text</div></textarea>" be serialised by this algorithm?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:43): <textarea></textarea>
a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d (21:45): for anyone interested in tracking: gecko figure/legend bug is 423721
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:46): (assming the elements are in the HTML namespace :) )
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:48): a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d: doesn't <legend> only imply fieldset if it's foudn directly in body?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:49): a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d: and is otherwise just dropped?

a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d (21:51): zcorpan: well....i think it used to be that way....in body or unknown element...but since the post-b4 parser update to allow unknown (e.g. html5) elements to contains blocks, this has cropped up
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:52): ah. haven't tested a build with the other fix in
a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d (21:52): grab latest nitely if you wanna test....there was a related checkin yesterday
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:53): Maybe someone should run the HTML5 parser tests in Firefox to try to find unintended consequences of that patch
a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d (21:54): little late in beta cycle to replace ff's html parser with html5lib, i'd think :)
a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d (21:55): sounds like a good idea though...since it hasn't made it to a beta release yet.  though code freeze for "last" beta is tonite

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:56): I'm not suggesting trying to make FF pass the tests - they're just a useful source of occasionally obscure HTML code that could be compared before/after the patch
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:59): yo
a75e2a9b031cc76149a92ee34b62852d (21:59): pretty much, unknown elements can now have block children....instead of having to wrap them in an inline (e.g. span) to get em in DOM
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (21:59): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: so I'm looking at the application cache spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:01): i'm assuming you have a question related to this section? :-)
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (22:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: actually, I have two! :)
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (22:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: first, I didn't see an applicationCache property on the window interface
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:02): yeah, known bug
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (22:03): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: and a small nit in 4.6.4, could p3 and p4 switch places?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:04): p3 and p4?
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (22:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: step 3 and step 4
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:05): what difference does it make?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:06): step 3 doesn't have any visible side-effects
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (22:06): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: none really, it's just that you don't need to define what the cache is until after step 4
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:06): i prefer to have all the definitions together
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:06): makes it easier to find them
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:06): blame my pascal upbringing :-)
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (22:07): OK, told you it was a small nit :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:09): http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3Ca%20href%3Da%3Eaa%3Cmarquee%3Eaa%3Ca%20href%3Db%3Ebb%3C%2Fmarquee%3Eaa is different in FF3 vs FF2
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:25): looks like every single news article about Safari 3.1 mentions HTML 5
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (22:26): what HTML 5 features does 3.1 have (over 3.0)?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:26): the biggest are the video and audio elements and (nearly all of) their APIs
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:27): (also some smaller things like getElementsByClassName)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:29): (of course, getElementsByClassName will probably get a lot more use in the near term)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:37): hmm... SSML?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:38): http://www.w3.org/TR/speech-synthesis/
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:38): looks like a weird version of HTML to me
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (22:41): 3.1 also implements the Database spec
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (22:52): hehe, http://diveintomark.org/archives/2008/03/18/translation-from-ms-speak-to-english-of-selected-portions-of-joel-spolskys-martin-headsets

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:55): wonders if he's intentionally misinterpreting "nobody has a way to test against the standard" as meaning testing browsers against standards, rather than testing web pages against standards

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (22:58): hsivonen: when validating xhtml with resolving external entities, v.nu complains about shape attributes on <a>, even though the markup didn't have shape=''. i understand that the dtd resolves them, but it's probably confusing and unhelpful for authors...
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (23:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: what happens if I setAttribute('manifest', ...) on the HTML element?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:04): nothing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:04): (as per the spec)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:04): the manifest attribute is only handled during parse time
84689f38c388923534f7a36f04cf6fc7 (23:07): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: oh, you are right - now why didn't I notice that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:08): search for "run the application cache selection algorithm"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:08): those are the only times that the attribute has any effect
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:08): the spec defines the handling for XML files, text/plain files, and HTML files (in the HTML parser)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:09): oh and for images and plugins
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:09): and error pages
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:09): man, i was thorough
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (23:11): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I'm not quite clear that Joel does mean "test web pages against standards", but he seems somewhat incoherent on that point
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:12): i think joel doesn't understand that you can have pragmatic standards
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:13): his argument seemed predicted on the concept of specs either being idealistic and unimplementable, draconian and unsuitable, or overly vague.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:13): he missed the "realistic and detailed" option
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:13): I'm not sure what his point was in his big rant
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:13): but I admit I didn't read the whole thing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:13): yeah me either
d84728437bac6bc18af69cfdd57bff63 (23:13): i started to read it but realized it kept going
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:13): to not understanding the point
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:13): (i did read it)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:15): his reasoning for why vista hasn't been the success that XP was seems somewhat flawed, imho

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:18): 4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9: do you have any discussion of the cell association algorithm anywhere? i'm curious to know which cases you were trying to solve

d84728437bac6bc18af69cfdd57bff63 (23:18): it just has some hickups
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (23:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I don't know if we have anything written down that's not in email
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:19): i didn't see much discussion in the e-mails, mostly just algorithms :-)
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (23:20): Basically it's optimized for tables like http://annevankesteren.nl/2007/09/tmb-overview and  http://sitesurgeon.co.uk/tables/tides/minimal.html
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (23:22): (which seems to be a fairly common general pattern)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:24): so a column (row) header's scope stops when it hits another header with the same width (height) and starting x (y) position?
4c202c4816405ce1463bf93605cba3f9 (23:25): Just the same with/height iirc although I guess maybe it should also consider the starting position
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:26): i guess i'm going to have to just look at a lot of tables and determine the best algorithm that covers those tables
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:26): yay for ben's work looking at tables
